highlights.context: Naval Ravikant has said, “To write a great book, you must first become the book.”2

idea_cards.title: To write a great book, you must first become the book.
motivation ritual
own_thoughts: Create a motivational ritual by consciously doing something you crave for just before you start doing the new habit you want to establish.
For example, in the evening, I eat a piece of chocolate just before I sit down and start writing.
This strategy will ensure that I associate positive feelings with the new habit I want to establish.

idea_cards.title: Plateau of Latent Potential
own_thoughts: The concept of 'plateau of latent potential' explains why you need to stick with a new habit to see some results.
At the beginning, you may not see or feel any progress while you are investing time and efforts.
This is because there is often a non-linear relationship between input and output, where, at the beginning, the results grow under-proportionally.
This phenomenon is called the plateau of latent potential, because, at some point, the results will catch-up and increase at a higher rate.
So, it is important to keep going when you try to improve a skill even though you might be disappointed by the initial results.

idea_cards.title: Habit stacking
own_thoughts: A very easy way to form a new habit is to combine a current habit with a new habit.

For example, I want to start the day with some mobility and stretching. I can do these exercises during the time I prepare my morning tea. So, as soon as I set up the water to boil I start my mobility exercises.
That way, I can leverage my current habit as a cue to initiate my new habit.

idea_cards.title: Immediate reinforcement
own_thoughts: immediate reinforcement adds a positive feedback to the ending of your new habit. this makes it more likely that you repeat the behavior.
For example, when you are working the boxing pads, a great coach will give you instant acoustic feedback so that you are more likely to repeat good movement patterns and get rid of bad ones.

idea_cards.title: Temptation bundling
own_thoughts: Immediately follow up a new habit you want to establish with a current habit you crave for.
For example, I allow myself to watch my favorite Youtube channel immediately after I have reviewed my to-do list.
Once you have formed the psychological connection between the behavior you want to establish with the behavior you crave for, the craving will spill over to the new habit.

idea_cards.title: Work hard on the things that come easy
Your outcomes are a lagging measure of your habits.
process of building a habit
own_thoughts: The habit formation process can be broken down into four steps.
The first is the cue. This is the starting point where an external trigger reminds you to initiate some behavior.
The next step is the craving as the motivational force behind every habit. It is the internal trigger that promts your behavior.
Then comes the response, which is the behavior itself.
The last step is the reward as the end goal of every habit.
What follows in the book is a systematic approach to influence your habits by taking action on every step of this habit formation process.

idea_cards.title: accountability partner
own_thoughts: An accountability partner adds immediate pain for violating your promises.
Having a David-Goggins-like training partner makes it really painful if you do not show up. ..I can already hear his voice in the back of my head..
With a great accountability partner you can really celebrate an attitude of embracing every challenge and never giving up.

idea_cards.title: explore/exploit trade-off
own_thoughts: When choosing where to focus on, you should strive for a balance between new activities that excite you and activities that match your natural skills.
You should ask yourself: When am I enjoying myself when others are complaining?

idea_cards.title: You should be far more concerned with your current trajectory than with your current results.

Environment design

THE CONTEXT IS THE CUE
Make the cues of good habits obvious in your environment.

entries.label: 7: The Secret to Self-Control

highlights.context: Self-control is a short-term strategy, not a long-term one.
One of the most practical ways to eliminate a bad habit is to reduce exposure to the cue that causes
“disciplined” people are better at structuring their lives in a way that does not require heroic willpower

nine out of ten soldiers who used heroin in Vietnam eliminated their addiction nearly overnight.3

Design your environment. Make the cues of good habits obvious and visible.
Make the cues of your good habits obvious and the cues of your bad habits invisible.
Use habit stacking: “After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT].”
People with high self-control tend to spend less time in tempting situations. It’s easier to avoid temptation
Once a habit is formed, it is unlikely to be forgotten.
Reduce exposure. Remove the cues of your bad habits from your environment.

idea_cards.title: Habit stacking
own_thoughts: A very easy way to form a new habit is to combine a current habit with a new habit.

For example, I want to start the day with some mobility and stretching. I can do these exercises during the time I prepare my morning tea. So, as soon as I set up the water to boil I start my mobility exercises.
That way, I can leverage my current habit as a cue to initiate my new habit.

idea_cards.title: Immediate reinforcement
own_thoughts: immediate reinforcement adds a positive feedback to the ending of your new habit. this makes it more likely that you repeat the behavior.
For example, when you are working the boxing pads, a great coach will give you instant acoustic feedback so that you are more likely to repeat good movement patterns and get rid of bad ones.

idea_cards.title: Temptation bundling
own_thoughts: Immediately follow up a new habit you want to establish with a current habit you crave for.
For example, I allow myself to watch my favorite Youtube channel immediately after I have reviewed my to-do list.
Once you have formed the psychological connection between the behavior you want to establish with the behavior you crave for, the craving will spill over to the new habit.

idea_cards.title: Work hard on the things that come easy
Your outcomes are a lagging measure of your habits.
process of building a habit
own_thoughts: The habit formation process can be broken down into four steps.
The first is the cue. This is the starting point where an external trigger reminds you to initiate some behavior.
The next step is the craving as the motivational force behind every habit. It is the internal trigger that promts your behavior.
Then comes the response, which is the behavior itself.
The last step is the reward as the end goal of every habit.
What follows in the book is a systematic approach to influence your habits by taking action on every step of this habit formation process.

idea_cards.title: accountability partner
own_thoughts: An accountability partner adds immediate pain for violating your promises.
Having a David-Goggins-like training partner makes it really painful if you do not show up. ..I can already hear his voice in the back of my head..
With a great accountability partner you can really celebrate an attitude of embracing every challenge and never giving up.

idea_cards.title: explore/exploit trade-off
own_thoughts: When choosing where to focus on, you should strive for a balance between new activities that excite you and activities that match your natural skills.
You should ask yourself: When am I enjoying myself when others are complaining?

idea_cards.title: You should be far more concerned with your current trajectory than with your current results.

idea_cards.title: Plateau of Latent Potential
own_thoughts: The concept of 'plateau of latent potential' explains why you need to stick with a new habit to see some results.
At the beginning, you may not see or feel any progress while you are investing time and efforts.
This is because there is often a non-linear relationship between input and output, where, at the beginning, the results grow under-proportionally.
This phenomenon is called the plateau of latent potential, because, at some point, the results will catch-up and increase at a higher rate.
So, it is important to keep going when you try to improve a skill even though you might be disappointed by the initial results.

data.label: Conclusion: The Secret to Results That Last

highlights.context: It’s remarkable what you can build if you just don't stop. It's remarkable the business you can build

idea_cards.title: To write a great book, you must first become the book.
motivation ritual
own_thoughts: Create a motivational ritual by consciously doing something you crave for just before you start doing the new habit you want to establish.
For example, in the evening, I eat a piece of chocolate just before I sit down and start writing.
This strategy will ensure that I associate positive feelings with the new habit I want to establish.

idea_cards.title: Plateau of Latent Potential
own_thoughts: The concept of 'plateau of latent potential' explains why you need to stick with a new habit to see some results.
At the beginning, you may not see or feel any progress while you are investing time and efforts.
This is because there is often a non-linear relationship between input and output, where, at the beginning, the results grow under-proportionally.
This phenomenon is called the plateau of latent potential, because, at some point, the results will catch-up and increase at a higher rate.
So, it is important to keep going when you try to improve a skill even though you might be disappointed by the initial results.

idea_cards.title: Habit stacking
own_thoughts: A very easy way to form a new habit is to combine a current habit with a new habit.

For example, I want to start the day with some mobility and stretching. I can do these exercises during the time I prepare my morning tea. So, as soon as I set up the water to boil I start my mobility exercises.
That way, I can leverage my current habit as a cue to initiate my new habit.

idea_cards.title: Immediate reinforcement
own_thoughts: immediate reinforcement adds a positive feedback to the ending of your new habit. this makes it more likely that you repeat the behavior.
For example, when you are working the boxing pads, a great coach will give you instant acoustic feedback so that you are more likely to repeat good movement patterns and get rid of bad ones.

idea_cards.title: Temptation bundling
own_thoughts: Immediately follow up a new habit you want to establish with a current habit you crave for.
For example, I allow myself to watch my favorite Youtube channel immediately after I have reviewed my to-do list.
Once you have formed the psychological connection between the behavior you want to establish with the behavior you crave for, the craving will spill over to the new habit.

idea_cards.title: Work hard on the things that come easy
Your outcomes are a lagging measure of your habits.
process of building a habit
own_thoughts: The habit formation process can be broken down into four steps.
The first is the cue. This is the starting point where an external trigger reminds you to initiate some behavior.
The next step is the craving as the motivational force behind every habit. It is the internal trigger that promts your behavior.
Then comes the response, which is the behavior itself.
The last step is the reward as the end goal of every habit.
What follows in the book is a systematic approach to influence your habits by taking action on every step of this habit formation process.

idea_cards.title: accountability partner
own_thoughts: An accountability partner adds immediate pain for violating your promises.
Having a David-Goggins-like training partner makes it really painful if you do not show up. ..I can already hear his voice in the back of my head..
With a great accountability partner you can really celebrate an attitude of embracing every challenge and never giving up.

idea_cards.title: explore/exploit trade-off
own_thoughts: When choosing where to focus on, you should strive for a balance between new activities that excite you and activities that match your natural skills.
You should ask yourself: When am I enjoying myself when others are complaining?

idea_cards.title: You should be far more concerned with your current trajectory than with your current results.

highlights.context: Success is not a goal to reach or a finish line to cross. It is a system to improve, an endless process
